--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> Here is a link to our new
> paper on evolving
> a roving eye for Go:
> 
> http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?stanley:gecco04

I just finished reading the paper, Ken.  Interesting
stuff.  The basic approach to the "roving eye" makes
sense...so does the way you implemented it.

I have a couple of questions, though.

What was the initial position of the eye at the
beginning of its turn?  Did it begin where it was
positioned at the end of the last turn, or does it
always start from a set position (e.g., the center)?

I notice that both the 5x5 and 7x7 roving eye players
form a vertical border down the center of the board as
effective strategies.  How would they react if the
play from GnuGo was transformed rotationally?

Is it possible the eye players are just memorizing a
sequence of moves against GnuGo?  GnuGo plays
deterministically, right?  Is the roving eye robust
enough to adapt if GnuGo plays slightly different from
game to game (e.g., rotating the board, slightly
randomizing its play)?

I've found, just experimenting with Tic-Tac-Toe, that
ANNs evolved against deterministic players are very
brittle.  Ones evolved against semi-random players
tend to be more robust in general.  

The roving eye networks were composed of 30 inputs and
5 outputs.  That means an initial minimal toplogy of
185 genes, correct?  (35 nodes + 150 connections.) 
You used a fairly low node mutation rate (0.0045) and
an add-connection mutation rate of (0.1).  What were
the sizes of some of your champion networks?  

Anyway...interesting stuff.  Thanks for sharing the
paper ahead of the conference.  It seems like a
potentially very fruitful approach.

Derek
